newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada says won't bail out Canadian.
newsitem.headline: Canada says won't bail out Canadian.

text.p: Canada's Transport Minister said on Monday that he thinks the financial restructuring plan of Canadian Airlines Corp will succeed without a federal government rescue of the ailing carrier.
"I don't think we will have a bankruptcy, because the Benson plan will work," David Anderson told reporters after a luncheon speech.

The minister was referring to a restructuring plan proposed by Canadian Airlines Chief Executive Kevin Benson, which includes, among other things, a 10 percent cut in the wages of the carrier's workers.
The Canadian Auto Workers (CAW), which represents 3,700 Canadian Airlines employees, has said it is opposed to the wage cutbacks.

Anderson said the Canadian government has ruled out floating Canadian Airlines with a grant or loan. The Calgary-based company's operating unit, Canadian Airlines International Ltd. (CAI) is Canada's second national air carrier.
"There is no question of (the government) investing or providing any loan," Anderson said.
The minister said the government would not step in with financial aid because Canadian has not asked for help and because Benson has said he would refuse such taxpayer assistance.
Anderson said it is up to Canadian, its employees and AMR Corp, which has a 33 percent stake in CAI, to agree on a viable restructuring plan.
"Proposals for simply throwing money at the problem instead of carrying out a restructuring of the problem in this situation would simply not work," Anderson said.
"After a loss over the last 10 years of C$1.3 billion we understand there must be a restructuring," he said.
Benson's restructuring plan includes a C$48 million reduction in service fees paid annually to Fort Worth, Texas-based AMR, which owns American Airlines. -- Reuters Montreal bureau (514) 985-2434
